page.title: 03Shiskine Valley - Farming
page.content: Farming is the main activity in the Shiskine valley. The land is used by fifteen different farmers. The farms are all quite small, most having fields on the valley floor given over to grass, rising to hill grazing for sheep and beef cattle on either side of the valley. Dairy farming is the most common, but some have beef cattle, and many have sheep as well. Most of the dairy herds are Friesians and the milk is collected by tanker and taken to the Kilmory Creamery for making into the famous Arran dunlop cheese. Hay is still made, but silage has become much more common. Other crops grown are barley and turnips for winter feed, and a few potatoes as a cash crop. One farmer specialises in soft fruit growing, and another in market gardening.
